@@ -45,6 +45,7 @@
 Different regions in Ukraine have their own distinctive style of [[vernacular architecture]], based on local traditions and the knowledge handed down through generations. The Museum of Folk Architecture and Way of Life of Central [[Naddnipryanshchyna]] is located in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]]. The open air museum contains 13 theme museums, 122 examples of national architecture, and over 30,000 historical cultural objects. The Museum of Decorative Finishes is one of the featured museums that preserves the handiwork of decorative architectural applications in [[Ukrainian architecture]]. Decorative finishes use ancient traditional design patterns.
 
 ===Ornamental and visual art===
+[[File:Hnizdovsky Rizdvo2.gif|thumbnail|[[Christmas in Ukraine|Christmas]] card by [[Jacques Hnizdovsky]]]]
 On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning. From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]] to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden. Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]].

 ====Weddings====
 {{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a wiling participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.

The Museum of Decorative Finishes is one of the featured museums that preserves the handiwork of decorative architectural applications in [[Ukrainian architecture]]. Decorative finishes use ancient traditional design patterns.

 An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.
 
-Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. @@ -9,7 +9,7 @@
 
 ====Weddings====
 {{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a wiling participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.
+Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.

 Ukraine greatly benefitted from the Soviet emphasis on [[physical education]], which left Ukraine with hundreds of stadiums, swimming pools, gymnasiums, and many other athletic facilities.
 
-[[Association football|Football]] is the most popular sport in Ukraine. The top professional league is the [[Vyscha Liha]], also known as the [[Ukrainian Premier League]]. Although Shakhtar is the reigning champion of the Vyscha Liha, Dynamo Kyiv has been much more successful historically, winning the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] two times, the [[UEFA Super Cup]] once, the [[Soviet Top League|USSR Championship]] a record 13 times, and the [[Ukrainian Premier League|Ukrainian Championship]] a record 12 times; while Shakhtar only won four Ukrainian Championships and one and last [[UEFA Cup]].

@@ -8,7 +8,7 @@
 
 ====Weddings====
 {{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.
+Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating. They play basketball in different ways.

@@ -48,7 +48,7 @@
 On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning. From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]] to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden. Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]].

-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. +===Holidays and celebrations ===
+[[File:Shepherds Bow - Google Art Project.jpg|thumbnail|[[Christmas in Ukraine|Christmas]] icon, [[Adoration of the Shepherds]], from the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]] collection. Artist unknown, c. 1670.]]
+{{See also|Public holidays in Ukraine}}Social gatherings like [[Vechornytsi]] have a long history in Ukrainian culture, and so do traditional [[Public holidays in Ukraine|holidays]] like [[Ivan Kupala Day]], [[Maslenitsa]], [[Koledovanie]], and [[Malanka]], where people gather in large groups. "[[Razom nas bahato, nas ne podolaty]]" is a popular cultural and political statement of both traditional and modern Ukrainians. It translates as "Together we are many! We cannot be defeated!"
+
+====Weddings====
+{{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
+Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.
+

 {{Main|Ukrainian dance}}
 [[Image:Rapid Trident 2014 06.jpg|thumb|The [[Hopak]] is often popularly referred to as the "National Dance of Ukraine". |right]]
 
-Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.
+Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[Kalyna (dance)|kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.
 * The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. If they wear a tunic, then under that they wear a long-sleeved richly [[Ukrainian embroidery|embroidered]] white shirt. Traditionally, women wear a type of red leather boots to dance in. They also wear a flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with [[flowers]] and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral [[necklaces]].
 * The men wear baggy [[trousers]] (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach. Over the shirt they sometimes will wear a richly embroidered [[vest]]. Around their waist they wear a thick sash with fringed ends. Like the women, they wear [[boots]], but these can be black or white in addition to red.
 * Kalyna dancing involves partner dancing. One dance, called the ''[[pryvitannia]]'', is a greeting dance. It is slow and respectful, the women bow to the audience and present bread with [[salt]] on a cloth and flowers. Another, called the [[hopak]] is much more lively, and involves many fast-paced movements. Hence hopak as a dance is derived from hopak martial art of [[Cossacks]].

 ====Traditional costume====
-For men, traditional dress includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[Å¼upan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[vyshyvanka]], [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
+The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]], is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May. For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[Å¼upan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
 
 ====Weaving and embroidery====
 Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|accessdate=30 December 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archivedate=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio]</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]].

 [[Food]] is an important part to the Ukrainian culture. Special foods are used at [[Easter]], as well as [[Christmas]]. During Christmas, for example, people prepare ''[[kutia]]'', which is a mixture of cooked wheat [[groats]], [[poppy seeds]], [[honey]], and special sweet breads.
 
-An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''Kolbasa'' ({{lang-ua|ÐšÐ¾Ð²Ð±Ð°ÑÐ°Ì, ''Kovbasa''}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." +An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''Kolbasa'' ({{lang-ua|ÐšÐ¾Ð²Ð±Ð°ÑÐ°Ì}}, {{lang|ua|script=latn|Kovbasa}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.
 
 Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Popular foods include [[Salo (food)|salo]], [[borscht]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[chicken kiev]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[pierogi]],and [[pilaf]].

+'''Ukrainian culture''' and customs of [[Ukraine]] and ethnic [[Ukrainians]]. Ukraine has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, dating back to the 9th century and the [[Rus (name)|Land of Rus]]. Mutual customs are shared among the cultures of  [[Ukraine]], [[Culture of Belarus|Belarus]], [[Ukrainian Cossacks]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]]. The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language.

@@ -56,6 +56,7 @@
 
 ====Traditional costume====
 The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]], is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May. For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[Å¼upan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
+[[File:Ð’Ð¸ÑˆÐ¸Ð²Ð°Ð½ÐºÐ¸ (Ð¡Ð²ÐµÑ‚Ð»Ð°Ð½Ð° Ð¡Ñ‚Ð¾ÑÐ»Ð¾Ð²Ð°).jpg|thumb|Ukrainian woman in Ukrainian clothes]]
 
 ====Weaving and embroidery====
 Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|accessdate=30 December 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archivedate=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio]</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]].

@@ -105,7 +105,7 @@
 
 [[Association football|Football]] is the most popular sport in Ukraine. The top professional league is the [[Vyscha Liha]], also known as the [[Ukrainian Premier League]]. The two most successful teams in the Vyscha Liha are rivals [[FC Dynamo Kyiv]] and [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk]]. Although Shakhtar is the reigning champion of the Vyscha Liha, Dynamo Kyiv has been much more successful historically, winning the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] two times, the [[UEFA Super Cup]] once, the [[Soviet Top League|USSR Championship]] a record 13 times, and the [[Ukrainian Premier League|Ukrainian Championship]] a record 12 times; while Shakhtar only won four Ukrainian Championships and one and last [[UEFA Cup]].
 
-Many Ukrainians also played for the [[USSR national football team]], most notably [[Igor Belanov]] and [[Oleg Blokhin]], winners of the prestigious [[Ballon d'Or|Golden Ball Award]] for the best footballers of the year. This award was only presented to one Ukrainian after the collapse of the Soviet Union, [[Andriy Shevchenko]], the current captain of the [[Ukraine national football team]]. The national team made its debut in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], and reached the quarter-finals before losing to eventual champions, [[Italy national football team|Italy]].
+Many Ukrainians also played for the [[USSR national football team]], most notably [[Igor Belanov]] and [[Oleg Blokhin]], winners of the prestigious [[Ballon d'Or|Golden Ball Award]] for the best footballers of the year. This award was only presented to one Ukrainian after the collapse of the Soviet Union, [[Andriy Shevchenko]], the former captain of the [[Ukraine national football team]]. The national team made its debut in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], and reached the quarter-finals before losing to eventual champions, [[Italy national football team|Italy]].
 
 Ukrainian brothers [[Vitaliy Klychko]] and [[Volodymyr Klychko]] have held world heavyweight champion titles in [[boxing]].

 ===Language===
 {{Main|Ukrainian language}}
 The main language is Ukrainian.

+===Respect for authority===
+Ukrainians have almost zero respect for authority. It can be seen in the they treat their government, for instance how they throw rotten eggs at them when people are dissatisfied with something or how they make up memes and jokes when politicians make some mistakes in any activity. Ukrainians also tend to ignore a lot of rules because of the absence of fear of being punished by authority. There is also a popular saying amongst population â€œThe severity of traffic rules in our country is compensated by the unnecessity of following themâ€. This massive lack of respect is mainly caused by huge distrust for any kind of state governance and its related departments. The latest social research <ref>https://strana.ua/articles/121996-pochemu-rejtinh-vlasti-upal-do-istoricheskoho-minimuma.html</ref> shows that only 12% of the population believes that their leaders and public servants make a good job of managing the countyâ€™s internal and external policies. Moreover, corruption in Ukraine thrives extremely, especially in the sphere of governance of any kind, so it also facilitates deeper disrespect for authority.
+

@@ -121,7 +121,13 @@
 ===Tourism===
 {{Main|Tourism in Ukraine}}
 Ukraine attracts more than 20 million visitors a year from around the world.<ref name=ukrstat>[http://www.ukrstat.gov.ua/operativ/operativ2007/tyr/tyr_u/potoki2006_u.htm Ð¢ÑƒÑ€Ð¸ÑÑ‚Ð¸Ñ‡Ð½Ñ– Ð¿Ð¾Ñ‚Ð¾ÐºÐ¸] {{uk icon}}, State Statistics Committee of Ukraine</ref> [[Seven Natural Wonders of Ukraine]] and [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] are popular destinations as well as modern urban cities, festivals, [[ecotourism]], and [[medical tourism]].
-{{clear}}
+
+=== '''Ukrainian market - Bazaar''' ===
+Bazaar is well-known mostly for marketplaces of Middle Eastern countries. But Ukrainians usually call an open market with the same word, less often - 'rynok'. Many Ukrainians who has been living during the Soviet Era, remember that Rynok or Bazaar was only one place where people could find all necessary things. Probably, that's why this type of shopping places is still popular in Ukraine. You can find such markets in every Ukrainian city or town. Â For example, [[Kiev|Kyiv]], the Ukrainian capital, is full of them and one of the most popular is the [[Besarabsky Market]]. In such markets people sell fresh seasonal vegetables, meat, fish, homemade cottage cheese, second-hand and new clothes, household things, books etc. In case you need something you don't even know where you can find it - just go to the Rynok, or how Ukrainians call it 'Na Bazaar', and ask. People there know everything.
+
+Bazaar or Rynok in Ukraine - it's not only about selling grocery - it is a whole social and even cultural phenomenon. People meet there, talk with each other, share the latest news and gossips. It is a different story how Ukrainian sellers praise and call to buy their goods. Big Ukrainian cities, for example, Kyiv, [[Lviv]], [[Kharkiv]], [[Dnipro]] is also known for the 'spontaneous markets'. It happens when people from countryside around the big city bring their homemade products and sell them in crowded places in the city: near the metro, in the central parts of the city, at the railway stations etc. Walking through the streets of the Ukrainian city you can stumble upon a cute (or not) 'babusya' (grandmother) asking you to buy one or two fresh apples/flowers/pears etc. Â 
+
+Compared to modern shiny shopping malls, the cityâ€™s markets might seem a little bit shabby, but in case you want to feel everyday Ukrainian soul you have definitely visit any Rynok you'll find.{{clear}}

 ===Respect for authority===
 Ukrainians have almost zero respect for authority. It can be seen in the they treat their government, for instance how they throw rotten eggs at them when people are dissatisfied with something or how they make up memes and jokes when politicians make some mistakes in any activity. Ukrainians also tend to ignore a lot of rules because of the absence of fear of being punished by authority. There is also a popular saying amongst population â€œThe severity of traffic rules in our country is compensated by the unnecessity of following themâ€. This massive lack of respect is mainly caused by huge distrust for any kind of state governance and its related departments. The latest social research <ref>https://strana.ua/articles/121996-pochemu-rejtinh-vlasti-upal-do-istoricheskoho-minimuma.html</ref> shows that only 12% of the population believes that their leaders and public servants make a good job of managing the countyâ€™s internal and external policies. Moreover, corruption in Ukraine thrives extremely, especially in the sphere of governance of any kind, so it also facilitates deeper disrespect for authority.
+
+
+
 ===Religion===
 {{Main|Religion in Ukraine}}
 [[Religion]] is practiced throughout the country. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] and [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Eastern Catholicism]] and [[Roman Catholic]] are the three most widely practiced religions. The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church]]<ref>{{cite web|title=CIA World Factbook|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/up.html|accessdate=16 March 2012}}</ref> is the largest in the country.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.ukraine-travel-advisor.com/ukraine-culture.html Ukraine Culture. Ukraine People. Education. Religion<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Faithful of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]], the second largest, practice [[Byzantine]] rites, but are united with the [[Roman Catholic Church]].
-
-=== Paying restaurant bills ===
-In most restaurants in Ukraine, the waiter will bring you your bill when you request for it after youâ€™ve had your meal. Most of the time the bill doesnâ€™t include a tip, so itâ€™s up to you to decide whether you want to tip the waiter or not. If there is a tip already included, itâ€™s generally around 10 to 13 percent of the cost of your food & drinks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.whototip.net/tipping-in-ukraine|website=www.whototip.net|access-date=2018-12-10}}</ref> It is considered quite rude not to leave a tip if the service you received was satisfactory, but if it was terrible or the waiter offended you in some way you are free to only pay for your order.
-
-You can always split the bill if you need to. In order to do that just let the waiter know you want to split it before you order or before you ask for the bill. Sometimes the drinks and the food might be split into two bills, itâ€™s totally normal, just depends on how the restaurant pays their taxes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://minfin.com.ua/ua/2017/10/09/30354580/|title=Ð”Ð²Ð° Ñ‡ÐµÐºÐ¸ Ð² Ñ€ÐµÑÑ‚Ð¾Ñ€Ð°Ð½Ñ–|website=minfin.com.ua|language=uk|access-date=2018-12-10}}</ref> Some restaurants have their own discount policy and hand in the discount cards to their frequent customers. If youâ€™ve purchased enough food in one sitting the waiter will ask you if you would like to receive your discount card and use it in the future.
-
-Paying with your card is a very popular option in Kyiv and other big Ukrainian cities. Since 2006 all department stores in Ukraine were requested to provide their customers with a possibility of paying with their credit cards. Soon after that a lot of restaurants and cafÃ©s adopted this custom and now you can pay with your card (or your phone, using ApplePay or GooglePay) in most restaurants and stores in Kyiv. Some waiters ask you what you paying method will be before they bring your bill, but if they donâ€™t you have to let them know youâ€™ll be paying with your card so they can bring the terminal over to your table. {{clear}}
+{{clear}}
 ==Cuisine==
 [[File:Borscht_served.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian [[borscht]] with [[smetana (dairy product)|smetana]]]]
 {{Main|Ukrainian cuisine}}

@@ -37,6 +37,18 @@
 An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''Kolbasa'' ({{lang-uk|ÐšÐ¾Ð²Ð±Ð°ÑÐ°Ì}}, {{lang|uk-latn|Kovbasa}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.
 
 Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Often they will drink [[tea]] (''[[Masala chai|chai]]''), [[wine]], or [[coffee]] afterwards with a simple dessert, such as a fruit pastry. Popular foods include [[Salo (food)|salo]], [[borscht]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[chicken kiev]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[pierogi]],and [[pilaf]].
+
+This detailed list should be started with borshch. This soup made of meat, beetroot, potato, cabbage and many other ingredients is one of the main dishes associated with Ukraine. Thereâ€™s no family who donâ€™t cook it on the weekends. There are a lot of different variants of this dish depending on the region of Ukraine, tastes or a chef, but it always tastes best when served with sour cream, bread and salo.
+
+Another famous dish is Chicken Kyiv, named after capital of Ukraine This dish made of chicken filet with a piece of butter and dill inside is famous across the world nowadays. It is even served in some fashionable restaurants in Europe and the USA.
+
+One more famous dish is varenyky. It is not only Ukrainian dish because in some countries it is also known as pierogi, but in Ukraine it tastes the best :)Ð†t is a kind of dumpling made of dough, but the filling depends on the imagination and taste preferences of the chef or family. Cabbages, meat, mushrooms, potatoes, cottage cheese, cherries or strawberry are the most typical fillings.
+
+Another dish is deruny, or potato pancakes, which may be fried or baked. They mostly are served with meat, mushrooms, onion or other additional ingredients. Also you can keep them simple and serve just with sour cream.
+
+One more Ukrainian national dish is golubtsi - traditional stuffed cabbage rolls. They take many hours to prepare properly and there are two ways to make them: bake them in the oven or stew them in a pan. Minced meat with rice wrapped in cabbage leaf requires fine culinary skills, but Ukrainian mothers and grandmothers do them perfectly!
+
+Among other national ukrainian dishes there are so many delicious ones, like pampushky, holodets, syrnyky, nalysnyky and many others, because Ukraine is rich in it.

 {{Culture of Ukraine}}
 '''Ukrainian culture''' is a composition of material and spiritual values of [[Ukrainian people]] that has formed throughout its history ([[Ukrainian history]]). It is closely intertwined with [[ethnic studies]] about ethnic Ukrainians and Ukrainian [[historiography]] which is focused on [[history of Kiev]] and region around it.
 
-The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendent of the Old Russian (Ruthenian) state centered in [[Kiev]] and known as [[Kievan Rus']]. Therefore it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian historian and Imperial Russian subject [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus''.
+Whilst the country has often struggled to preserve its independence its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's rich literary history such as [[Taras Shevchenko]] and [[Ivan Franko]]. The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgence since the establishment of independence in 1991.
 
-Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]]. The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language.
+The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendent of the ancient state of [[Kievan Rus']] centered in [[Kiev]] as well the [[Kingdom of Galiciaâ€“Volhynia]], both of which Ukrainians claim as their historical ancestors. Therefore it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian historian, academic and politician of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian Peoples Republic,]] [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus,'' emphasising Ukraines historical claim to the ancient state of Kievan Rus. 
 
-The idea of Ukrainian culture and ethnic studies has its controversies. According to modern Russian ethnic studies and historiography Ukrainian culture and Ukrainian nation is part of bigger [[triune Russian nation]], where Russians are dominant ethnic group and Ukrainians are simply its regional branch. At the same time Ukrainian culture has a lot of commonalities with [[Polish culture]] and [[Belarusian culture]], lesser extent [[Yiddish culture]], due to being related for many centuries to the former [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]]. In addition Ukrainian culture has special relations with Moldavian culture which is part of bigger [[Vlach nation]] today politically realized as country of [[Romania]].
+Traditional peasant folk art, embroidery and vernacular architecture are critiacl to Ukrainian culture, and its elements have often been determined by the resources available at the time. The countries strong tradition of folk art and embroidery continues to this day, with [[Ukrainian embroidery]] often considered an art form in itself. 
+
+Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]]. The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language and led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics culture and identity. Because of the countries unique positions its culture has been influenced by both Western Europe, Russia and Asia.
+
+Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past have often implemented policies aimed at integrating the endemic population into their occupiers own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture for example the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture. 
+
+Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ to their Gregorian counterparts, these include Christmas and New Years Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>
+

 The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]], is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May. For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[Å¼upan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
 
 ====Weaving and embroidery====
-Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives.  ====Weddings====
 {{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.

 Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Ukrainian historian, academic and politician of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus,'' emphasising Ukraines historical claim to the ancient state of Kievan Rus. 
 
 Traditional peasant folk art, embroidery and vernacular architecture are critical to Ukrainian culture, and its elements have often been determined by the resources available at the time. The country's strong tradition of folk art and embroidery continues to this day, with [[Ukrainian embroidery]] often considered an art form in itself. 
 
 Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]]. The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language and led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics culture and identity. Because of the country's location its culture has been influenced by both Europe and Asia.
 
-Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture. 
 
 Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ from their Gregorian counterparts. These include Christmas and New Year's Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|date=17 July 2018|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>

@@ -85,7 +85,7 @@
 Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[Kalyna (dance)|kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.
 * The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. If they wear a tunic, then under that they wear a long-sleeved richly [[Ukrainian embroidery|embroidered]] white shirt. Traditionally, women wear a type of red leather boots to dance in. They also wear a flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with [[flowers]] and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral [[necklaces]].
 * The men wear baggy [[trousers]] (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach. Over the shirt they sometimes will wear a richly embroidered [[vest]]. Around their waist they wear a thick sash with fringed ends. Like the women, they wear [[Boot|boots]], but these can be black or white in addition to red.
-* Kalyna dancing involves partner dancing. One dance, called the ''[[pryvitannia]]'', is a greeting dance. It is slow and respectful, the women bow to the audience and present bread with [[salt]] on a cloth and flowers. Another, called the [[hopak]] is much more lively, and involves many fast-paced movements. Hence hopak as a dance is derived from hopak martial art of [[Cossacks]].
+* Kalyna dancing involves partner dancing. One dance, called the ''[[pryvitannia|pryvitannya]]'', is a greeting dance. It is slow and respectful, the women bow to the audience and present bread with [[salt]] on a cloth and flowers. Another, called the [[hopak]] is much more lively, and involves many fast-paced movements. Hence hopak as a dance is derived from hopak martial art of [[Cossacks]].

-{{See also|Public holidays in Ukraine}}Social gatherings like [[Vechornytsi]] have a long history in Ukrainian culture, and so do traditional [[Public holidays in Ukraine|holidays]] like [[Ivan Kupala Day]], [[Maslenitsa]], [[Koledovanie|Koledowanie]], and [[Malanka]], where people gather in large groups. +{{See also|Public holidays in Ukraine}}Social gatherings like [[Vechornytsi]] have a long history in Ukrainian culture, and so do traditional [[Public holidays in Ukraine|holidays]] like [[Ivan Kupala Day]], [[Maslenitsa]], [[Koledovanie|Koledowanie]], and [[Malanka]], where people gather in large groups. "[[Razom nas bahato, nas ne podolaty]]" is a popular cultural and political statement of both traditional and modern Ukrainians. It translates as "Together we are many!  ====Weddings====
 {{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.
+Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.<ref>{{cite web |title=Weddings at Soyuzivka |url=http://www.weddingsatsoyuzivka.com/traditions.html |website=Ukrainian Wedding Traditions |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

 [[Food]] is an important part to the Ukrainian culture. Special foods are used at [[Easter]], as well as [[Christmas]]. During Christmas, for example, people prepare ''[[kutia]]'', which is a mixture of cooked wheat [[groats]], [[poppy seeds]], [[honey]], and special sweet breads.
 
-An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''Kolbasa'' ({{lang-uk|ÐšÐ¾Ð²Ð±Ð°ÑÐ°Ì}}, {{lang|uk-latn|Kovbasa}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." -Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[Kalyna (dance)|kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.
-* The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. If they wear a tunic, then under that they wear a long-sleeved richly [[Ukrainian embroidery|embroidered]] white shirt. Traditionally, women wear a type of red leather boots to dance in. They also wear a flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with [[flowers]] and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral [[necklaces]].
-* The men wear baggy [[trousers]] (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach. Over the shirt they sometimes will wear a richly embroidered [[vest]]. Around their waist they wear a thick sash with fringed ends. Like the women, they wear [[Boot|boots]], but these can be black or white in addition to red.
-* Kalyna dancing involves partner dancing. One dance, called the ''[[pryvitannia|pryvitannya]]'', is a greeting dance. It is slow and respectful, the women bow to the audience and present bread with [[salt]] on a cloth and flowers. Another, called the [[hopak]] is much more lively, and involves many fast-paced movements. Hence hopak as a dance is derived from hopak martial art of [[Cossacks]].

 {{Culture of Ukraine}}
 '''Ukrainian culture''' is the composite of the material and spiritual values of the [[Ukrainian people]] that has formed throughout its [[Ukrainian history|history]]. It is closely intertwined with [[ethnic studies]] about ethnic Ukrainians and Ukrainian [[historiography]] which is focused on [[history of Kyiv]] and region around it.<ref name="Conv_Kyiv">{{cite web |title=Ukraine as a â€˜borderlandâ€™ |url=https://theconversation.com/ukraine-as-a-borderland-a-brief-history-of-ukraines-place-between-europe-and-russia-178168 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

+Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence<ref name="Brit_Ukraine">{{cite web |title=Ukraine |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's literary history such as [[Taras Shevchenko]]<ref name="EoU_Shevchenko">{{cite web |title=Shevchenko, Taras |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108142329/http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and [[Ivan Franko]].<ref name="EoU_Franko">{{cite web |title=Franko, Ivan |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/F/R/FrankoIvan.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgenc<ref name="Brit_KyivanRus">{{cite web |title=Kyivan Rus |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kyivan-Rus |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>e since the establishment of independence in 1991.
 
 The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendant of the ancient state of [[Kyivan Rus']] centered in [[Kyiv]] as well the [[Kingdom of Galiciaâ€“Volhynia]], both of which Ukrainians claim as their historical ancestors.<ref name="Brit_Galicia">{{cite web |title=Galicia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Galicia-historical-region-Eastern-Europe |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref><ref name="Brit_Volhynia">{{cite web |title=Volhynia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Volhynia |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Therefore it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian historian, academic and politician of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus,'' emphasising Ukraines historical claim to the ancient state of Kievan Rus. 
 
 Traditional peasant folk art, embroidery and vernacular architecture are critical to Ukrainian culture, and its elements have often been determined by the resources available at the time. The country's strong tradition of folk art and embroidery continues to this day, with [[Ukrainian embroidery]] often considered an art form in itself. 
 
-Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]<ref name="ARDA_Orth">{{cite web |title=Orthodox Christians |url=https://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_231_2.asp |website=ARDA |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]]<ref name="Brit_SlavRel">{{cite web |title=Britannica |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Slavic-religion |website=Slavic religion |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>. The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language and led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics culture and identity. Ukrainian culture has had heavy influence from other East Slavic cultures such as [[Culture of Russia|Russian]] and [[Belarusian culture]].<ref name="Conv_RusUk">{{cite web |title=How Russian is Ukraine? |url=https://theconversation.com/how-russian-is-ukraine-clue-not-as-much-as-vladimir-putin-insists-173758 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. @@ -85,7 +85,7 @@
 
 Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[Kalyna (dance)|kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.<ref name="Kalyna">{{cite web |title=Chervona Kalyna |url=https://kalyna.org/ |website=Kalyna |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 * The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. If they wear a tunic, then under that they wear a long-sleeved richly [[Ukrainian embroidery|embroidered]] white shirt. Traditionally, women wear a type of red leather boots to dance in. They also wear a flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with [[flowers]] and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral [[necklaces]].<ref name="UNF_Kalyna">{{cite web |title=Kalyna Performing Arts Company |url=https://unfcanada.ca/programs/kalyna/ |website=UNF Canada |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
-* The men wear baggy [[trousers]] (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach. Over the shirt they sometimes will wear a richly embroidered [[vest]]. Around their waist they wear a thick sash with fringed ends. Like the women, they wear [[Boot|boots]], but these can be black or white in addition to red.<ref name="UNF_Kalyna"/>
+* The men wear baggy [[trousers]] (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach. Over the shirt they sometimes will wear a richly embroidered [[vest]]. Around their waist they wear a thick sash with fringed ends. Like the women, they wear [[boot]]s, but these can be black or white in addition to red.<ref name="UNF_Kalyna"/>
 * Kalyna dancing involves partner dancing. One dance, called the ''[[pryvitannia|pryvitannya]]'', is a greeting dance. It is slow and respectful, the women bow to the audience and present bread with [[salt]] on a cloth and flowers. Another, called the [[hopak]] is much more lively, and involves many fast-paced movements. Hence hopak as a dance is derived from hopak martial art of [[Cossacks]].<ref name="Brit_Hopak">{{cite web |title=Hopak |url=https://www.britannica.com/art/hopak |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

 Ukrainian brothers [[Vitaliy Klychko]] and [[Volodymyr Klychko]] have held world heavyweight champion titles in [[boxing]].<ref name="KM_Klitschko">{{cite web |title=Klitschko Museum |url=https://klitschkomuseum.com/en/about |website=Klitschko Museum |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

 Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture.  Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence<ref name="Brit_Ukraine">{{cite web |title=Ukraine |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's literary history such as [[Taras Shevchenko]]<ref name="EoU_Shevchenko">{{cite web |title=Shevchenko, Taras |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108142329/http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |archive-date=8 January 2018 |url-status=dead}}</ref> and [[Ivan Franko]].<ref name="EoU_Franko">{{cite web |title=Franko, Ivan |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/F/R/FrankoIvan.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgenc<ref name="Brit_KyivanRus">{{cite web |title=Kyivan Rus |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kyivan-Rus |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> e since the establishment of independence in 1991.
 
-The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendant of the ancient state of [[Kyivan Rus']] centered in [[Kyiv]] as well the [[Kingdom of Galiciaâ€“Volhynia]], both of which Ukrainians claim as their historical ancestors.<ref name="Brit_Galicia">{{cite web |title=Galicia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Galicia-historical-region-Eastern-Europe |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref><ref name="Brit_Volhynia">{{cite web |title=Volhynia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Volhynia |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Therefore it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian historian, academic and politician of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus,'' emphasising Ukraines historical claim to the ancient state of Kievan Rus.
+The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendant of the ancient state of [[Kyivan Rus']] centered in [[Kyiv]] as well the [[Kingdom of Galiciaâ€“Volhynia]], both of which Ukrainians claim as their historical ancestors.<ref name="Brit_Galicia">{{cite web |title=Galicia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Galicia-historical-region-Eastern-Europe |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref><ref name="Brit_Volhynia">{{cite web |title=Volhynia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Volhynia |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Therefore, it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian historian, academic and politician of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus,'' emphasising Ukraines historical claim to the ancient state of Kievan Rus.
 
 Traditional peasant folk art, embroidery and vernacular architecture are critical to Ukrainian culture, and its elements have often been determined by the resources available at the time. The country's strong tradition of folk art and embroidery continues to this day, with [[Ukrainian embroidery]] often considered an art form in itself.

-Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]<ref name="ARDA_Orth">{{cite web |title=Orthodox Christians |url=https://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_231_2.asp |website=ARDA |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]].<ref name="Brit_SlavRel">{{cite web |title=Britannica |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Slavic-religion |website=Slavic religion |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language and led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics culture and identity. Ukrainian culture has had heavy influence from other East Slavic cultures such as [[Culture of Russia|Russian]] and [[Belarusian culture]].<ref name="Conv_RusUk">{{cite web |title=How Russian is Ukraine? |url=https://theconversation.com/how-russian-is-ukraine-clue-not-as-much-as-vladimir-putin-insists-173758 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
+Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]<ref name="ARDA_Orth">{{cite web |title=Orthodox Christians |url=https://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_231_2.asp |website=ARDA |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]].<ref name="Brit_SlavRel">{{cite web |title=Britannica |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Slavic-religion |website=Slavic religion |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language and led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics' culture and identity. Ukrainian culture has had heavy influence from other East Slavic cultures such as [[Culture of Russia|Russian]] and [[Belarusian culture]].<ref name="Conv_RusUk">{{cite web |title=How Russian is Ukraine? |url=https://theconversation.com/how-russian-is-ukraine-clue-not-as-much-as-vladimir-putin-insists-173758 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture.<ref name="Conv_RusUk"/>

 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture.<ref name="Conv_RusUk"/>

 Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message, if a pumpkin is given then the bridegroom can find one of the friends of the bride to see who is interested and begin the courtship process again if he finds one of the friends of the girlfriend is interested if the parents of the girlfriend gave a pumpkin, (this is specifically a Ukrainian traditional custom), the parents they usually ask for a moment before giving a final reply to see if the daughter is interested in private without the boyfriend being present while he is waiting in the guestroom. living room for the reply, if the girlfriend is not interested or if the parents find the man unsuitable for their daughter, then the father comes forward and gives a pumpkin, but even though a pumpkin is not the end of the world, for the boyfriend means the end of a relationship and that means that one of the friends of the bride he can show his interest, in that case and see if one of them is interested in him then they begin the relationship, still nowadays the tradition is the relationship ideally between the courtship process all the way to marriage should no longer than 2 years.

 once the young man and young woman reach an agreement , as long as the pumpkin is not given and the parents fully consent and give the blessing, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples each one carries an wedding icon the lady carries the Virgin Mary and the man carries the icon of Our Lord (both icons need to be previously blessed by a priest) once this happens the couple holds the icon as the parents give the blessing to them with another traditional custom. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents.  ===Architecture ===
 {{Main|Ukrainian architecture}}
-Ukrainian architecture reflects distinct features of that particular location and time period. Design and architecture are influenced by the existing political and economic climate.
+Ukrainian architecture reflects distinct features of that particular location and time period. Design and architecture are influenced by the existing political and economic climate.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
 ====Vernacular architecture====
 Different regions in Ukraine have their own distinctive style of [[vernacular architecture]], based on local traditions and the knowledge handed down through generations.<ref name="EoU_Arch">{{cite web |title=Folk architecture |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CF%5CO%5CFolkarchitecture.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Museum of Folk Architecture and Way of Life of Central [[Naddnipryanshchyna]] is located in [[Pereiaslav]]. The open-air museum contains 13 theme museums, 122 examples of national architecture, and over 30,000 historical cultural objects.<ref name="KI_FolkMuseum">{{cite web |title=Museum of Folk Architecture  and Rural Life |url=https://www.kiev.info/culture/folk_architecture.htm |website=Kiev.info |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Museum of Decorative Finishes is one of the featured museums that preserves the handiwork of decorative architectural applications in [[Ukrainian architecture]]. Decorative finishes use ancient traditional design patterns.<ref name="EoU_DecArt">{{cite web |title=National Museum of Ukrainian Decorative Folk Art |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CN%5CA%5CNationalMuseumofUkrainianDecorativeFolkArt.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

+[[Association football|Football]] is the most popular sport in Ukraine. The top professional league is the [[Vyscha Liha]], also known as the [[Ukrainian Premier League]].<ref name="Bets_Vyscha">{{cite web |title=Ukraine Vyscha Liga |url=https://betsapi.com/l/151/Ukraine-Vyscha-Liga |website=BetsAPI |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The two most successful teams in the Vyscha Liha are rivals [[FC Dynamo Kyiv]] and [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk]]. Although Shakhtar is the reigning champion of the Vyscha Liha, Dynamo Kyiv has been much more successful historically, winning the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] two times, the [[UEFA Super Cup]] once, the [[Soviet Top League|USSR Championship]] a record 13 times, and the [[Ukrainian Premier League|Ukrainian Championship]] a record 12 times; while Shakhtar only won four Ukrainian Championships and one and last [[UEFA Cup]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
 Many Ukrainians also played for the [[USSR national football team]], most notably [[Igor Belanov]] and [[Oleg Blokhin]], winners of the prestigious [[Ballon d'Or|Golden Ball Award]] for the best footballers of the year. This award was only presented to one Ukrainian after the collapse of the Soviet Union, [[Andriy Shevchenko]],<ref name="CBC_goldball">{{cite web |title=Ukrainian Andriy Shevchenko wins Golden Ball |url=https://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/ukrainian-andriy-shevchenko-wins-golden-ball-1.480117 |website=CBC |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> the former captain of the [[Ukraine national football team]].<ref name="Hyper_cap">{{cite web |title=List of Ukraine national football team captains |url=https://hyperleap.com/topic/List_of_Ukraine_national_football_team_captains |website=Hyperleap |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The national team made its debut in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], and reached the quarter-finals before losing to eventual champions, [[Italy national football team|Italy]].{{citation needed|date=March 2022}}

 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture.<ref name="Conv_RusUk"/>
 
 Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture.  ==History==
 [[File:Pektoral111.JPG|thumb|Gold Pectoral from [[Tovsta Mohyla]]|alt=Gold ornament of the Scythian era discovered at Tovsta Mohyla]]
+[[File: Basilica interior of St. Sophia Cathedral 03.jpg|thumb|Interior of [[Saint Sophia Cathedral, Kyiv|Saint Sophia Cathedral]] in Kyiv]] 
 Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence<ref name="Brit_Ukraine">{{cite web |title=Ukraine |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's literary history such as [[Ivan Kotliarevsky]], [[Taras Shevchenko]]<ref name="EoU_Shevchenko">{{cite web |title=Shevchenko, Taras |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108142329/http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |archive-date=8 January 2018 |url-status=dead}}</ref> and [[Ivan Franko]].<ref name="EoU_Franko">{{cite web |title=Franko, Ivan |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/F/R/FrankoIvan.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgence<ref name="Brit_KyivanRus">{{cite web |title=Kyivan Rus |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kyivan-Rus |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>{{failed verification|date=August 2022}} since the establishment of independence in 1991.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
 The earliest evidence of [[Cultural artifact|cultural artefacts]] in the Ukrainian lands can be traced to decorated [[mammoth]] tusks in the Neanderthal era.{{sfn|Kurkov|2022|p=24}} Later, the [[Nomad|nomadic tribes]] of the southern lands of the 4th century BCE, like the [[Scythians]], produced finely worked gold ornaments such as the pectoral found in the [[Tovsta Mohyla]] mound.{{sfn|Kurkov|2022|p=25}}

 Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholicism]], [[Ruthenian Greek Catholic Church|Ruthenian Greek Catholicism]] and [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]<ref name="ARDA_Orth">{{cite web |title=Orthodox Christians |url=https://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_231_2.asp |website=ARDA |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]].<ref name="Brit_SlavRel">{{cite web |title=Britannica |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Slavic-religion |website=Slavic religion |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> 
 Prior to the [[Soviet Union]], the Ukrainian culture has had heavy influence from other East Slavic cultures such as [[Culture of Russia|Russian]] and [[Belarusian culture]].<ref name="Conv_RusUk">{{cite web |title=How Russian is Ukraine? |url=https://theconversation.com/how-russian-is-ukraine-clue-not-as-much-as-vladimir-putin-insists-173758 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
-
+gay
 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture.<ref name="Conv_RusUk"/>
 
 Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ from their Gregorian counterparts.<ref name="EMP_Julian">{{cite web |title=Christmas on January 7 |url=https://euromaidanpress.com/2016/12/25/why-does-ukraine-celebrate-christmas-on-january-7-not-december-25/ |website=Euromaidan Press |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> These include Christmas and New Year's Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|date=17 July 2018|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>

+== Impact on culture due to Russian aggression ==
+During the Russian aggression against Ukraine, not only Ukrainian citizens and infrastructure, but also cultural [[heritage]] were targeted by the enemy. Destruction of monuments, attacks on educational and cultural institutions, robbery of museums - this is far from a complete list of crimes. Their number and the testimony of the employees of the affected institutions prove that it is not about individual excesses, but about a systematic and purposeful policy. Cultural heritage was targeted by the occupiers not by chance, but through purposeful [[Culture|cultural]] [[racism]].
+During the year of the full-scale war, 1,332 objects of cultural infrastructure were destroyed: [[Theatre|theaters]], [[philharmonic]] halls, [[Museum|museums]], [[galleries]], [[Library|libraries]], [[Club|clubs]]. More than a third of them are destroyed. As of mid-May 2023, the list of destroyed cultural monuments and objects of cultural heritage included more than 620 items.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Russians damage 1,946 cultural landmarks in two years of full-scale war against Ukraine |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/eng/news/2024/03/7/7445420/ |access-date=2024-03-10 |website=Ukrainska Pravda |language=en}}</ref>
+
