 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture.<ref name="Conv_RusUk"/>
 
 Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ from their Gregorian counterparts.<ref name="EMP_Julian">{{cite web |title=Christmas on January 7 |url=https://euromaidanpress.com/2016/12/25/why-does-ukraine-celebrate-christmas-on-january-7-not-december-25/ |website=Euromaidan Press |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> These include Christmas and New Year's Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|date=17 July 2018|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>

-====Weddings====
-{{more citations needed|section|date=August 2022}}
-{{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there is a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for the [[Bride price|dowry]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents' permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message, if a pumpkin is given then the bridegroom can find one of the friends of the bride to see who is interested and begin the courtship process again if he finds one of the friends of the girlfriend is interested if the parents of the girlfriend gave a pumpkin, (this is specifically a Ukrainian traditional custom), the parents they usually ask for a moment before giving a final reply to see if the daughter is interested in private without the boyfriend being present while he is waiting in the guestroom. living room for the reply, if the girlfriend is not interested or if the parents find the man unsuitable for their daughter, then the father comes forward and gives a pumpkin, but even though a pumpkin is not the end of the world, for the boyfriend means the end of a relationship and that means that one of the friends of the bride he can show his interest, in that case and see if one of them is interested in him then they begin the relationship, still nowadays the tradition is the relationship ideally between the courtship process all the way to marriage should no longer than two years.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
-
-Unlike the West where people can question the parents, in Ukrainian culture if the boyfriend is given a pumpkin he cannot ask why he was declined.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2018-11-15 |title=Ð’ÐµÑÑ–Ð»Ð»Ñ |url=https://ridna-ukraina.com.ua/traditions/vesillia.html |website=Ð Ñ–Ð´Ð½Ð° Ð£ÐºÑ€Ð°Ñ—Ð½Ð° |language=uk}}</ref> However, that means that the groom has to respect it and move on.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}} In Ukrainian culture, as well as most Slavic and Eastern cultures, it is considered very rude for someone younger, even if they are not part of the same family, to question parents.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
-
-Once the young man and young woman reach an agreement and the parents fully consent and give the blessing, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples each one carries a wedding icon the lady carries the Theotokos and the man carries the icon of Our Lord (both icons need to be previously blessed by a priest) once this happens the couple holds the icon as the parents give the blessing to them with another traditional custom. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.<ref>{{cite web |title=Weddings at Soyuzivka |url=http://www.weddingsatsoyuzivka.com/traditions.html |website=Ukrainian Wedding Traditions |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

-===Language===
-{{Main|Ukrainian language}}
-The main language is Ukrainian. However, most of the Ukrainian citizens also speak Russian.
-Almost all Ukrainians know the Russian language. As for foreign languages, English or German are mainly taught in schools.

 ===Religion===
 {{Main|Religion in Ukraine}}
 [[Religion]] is practiced throughout the country. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] and [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Eastern Catholicism]] and [[Roman Catholic]]ism are the three most widely practiced religions. The [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine|Ukrainian Orthodox Church]]<ref>{{cite web|title=CIA World Factbook|url=https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/ukraine/|access-date=16 March 2012}}</ref> is the largest in the country.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ukraine-travel-advisor.com/ukraine-culture.html |title=Ukraine Culture. Ukraine People. Education. Religion<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2010-05-04 |archive-date=2010-09-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100904054142/http://www.ukraine-travel-advisor.com/ukraine-culture.html |url-status=dead }}</ref> Faithful of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]], the second largest, practice [[Byzantine]] rites, but are in communion with the [[Roman Catholic Church]] which means that they are also fully Catholic.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}

-==Cuisine==
-[[File:Borscht served.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian [[borscht]] with [[smetana (dairy product)|smetana]]]]
-{{Main|Ukrainian cuisine}}
-{{See also|Ukrainian wine}}
-[[Food]] is an important part to the Ukrainian culture. Special foods are used at [[Easter]], as well as [[Christmas]]. During Christmas, for example, people prepare ''[[kutia]]'', which is a mixture of cooked wheat [[groats]], [[poppy seeds]], [[honey]], and special sweet breads.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Ð¡Ð»Ð¾Ð²Ð½Ð¸Ðº ÑƒÐºÑ€Ð°Ñ—Ð½ÑÑŒÐºÐ¾Ñ— Ð¼Ð¾Ð²Ð¸ Ð² 11 Ñ‚Ð¾Ð¼Ð°Ñ… |publisher=ÐÐ°ÑƒÐºÐ¾Ð²Ð° Ð´ÑƒÐ¼ÐºÐ° |editor-last=Ð‘Ñ–Ð»Ð¾Ð´Ñ–Ð´ |editor-first=Ð†Ð²Ð°Ð½ |location=ÐšÐ¸Ñ—Ð² |language=uk |chapter=ÐšÑƒÑ‚Ñ |chapter-url=http://sum.in.ua/s/kutja}}</ref>
-
-An average Ukrainian diet includes [[cheese]] and a variety of [[sausages]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2023}} [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''kovbasa'' ({{lang-uk|ÐºÐ¾Ð²Ð±Ð°ÑÐ°|links=no}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete".<ref name="EoU_Foods">{{cite web |title=Traditional foods |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CT%5CR%5CTraditionalfoods.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[Egg decorating in Slavic culture|pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.<ref name="UA_Pysanka">{{cite web |title=Pysanka |url=http://www.artsrn.ualberta.ca/ukisite/ukisite/pysanka/pysanka.htm |website=University of Alberta |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
-
-Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Often they will drink [[tea]] (''[[Masala chai|chai]]''), [[wine]], or [[coffee]] afterwards with a simple dessert, such as a fruit pastry. Popular foods include [[Salo (food)|salo]], [[borscht]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[chicken Kiev]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[Pierogi#Ukraine|varenyky]], [[Cabbage roll|holubtsi]], and [[Syrniki|syrnyky]].<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-08-19 |title=What is traditional food of Ukraine? |url=https://ukraine.ua/faq/how-to-cook-traditional-ukrainian-food/ |website=Official website of Ukraine}}</ref>

-===Performance art===
-====Dance====
-{{Main|Ukrainian dance}}
-[[File:Rapid Trident 2014 06.jpg|thumb|The [[Hopak]] is often popularly referred to as the "National Dance of Ukraine".{{Citation needed|reason=Source please.|date=August 2022}}|right]]
-
-Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[Kalyna (dance)|kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.<ref name="Kalyna">{{cite web |title=Chervona Kalyna |url=https://kalyna.org/ |website=Kalyna |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
-* The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. If they wear a tunic, then under that they wear a long-sleeved richly embroidered white shirt. Traditionally, women wear a type of red leather boots to dance in. They also wear a flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with [[flowers]] and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral [[necklaces]].<ref name="UNF_Kalyna">{{cite web |title=Kalyna Performing Arts Company |url=https://unfcanada.ca/programs/kalyna/ |website=UNF Canada |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
-* The men wear baggy [[trousers]] (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach. Over the shirt they sometimes will wear a richly embroidered [[vest]]. Around their waist they wear a thick sash with fringed ends. Like the women, they wear [[boot]]s, but these can be black or white in addition to red.<ref name="UNF_Kalyna"/>
-* Kalyna dancing involves partner dancing. One dance, called the ''[[pryvitannia]]'', is a greeting dance. It is slow and respectful, the women bow to the audience and present bread with [[salt]] on a cloth and flowers. Another, called the [[hopak]] is much more lively, and involves many fast-paced movements. Hence hopak as a dance is derived from hopak martial art of [[Cossacks]].<ref name="Brit_Hopak">{{cite web |title=Hopak |url=https://www.britannica.com/art/hopak |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

+=== Music ===

 == Crimean Tatars ==
-[[Crimean Tatars]] are the [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous people]] of the [[Crimea]].
+{{see also|Crimean Tatar language|Crimean Tatar literature}}[[Crimean Tatars]] are the [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous people]] of the [[Crimea]].
+[[File:Crimean_tatar_musician.jpg|thumb|Crimean Tatar musician]]
+[[Yurts]] or nomadic tents have traditionally played an important role in the cultural history of Crimean Tatars. There are different types of yurts; some are large and collapsible, called "terme", while others are small and non-collapsible (otav).
+
+On the [[Nowruz]] holiday, Crimean Tatars usually cook eggs, chicken soup, puff meat pie (kobete), [[halva]], and sweet biscuits. Children put on masks and sing special songs under the windows of their neighbours, receiving sweets in return.
+
+The songs (makam) of the nomadic steppe Crimean Tatars are characterized by diatonic, melodic simplicity and brevity. The songs of mountainous and southern coastal Crimean Tatars, called {{lang|crh-Latn|TÃ¼rkÃ¼}}, are sung with richly ornamented melodies. Household [[lyricism]] is also widespread. Occasionally, song competitions take place between young men and women during Crimean holidays and weddings. Ritual [[folklore]] includes winter greetings, wedding songs, lamentations and circular dance songs (khoran). Epic stories or destans are very popular among the Crimean Tatars, particularly the destans of "Chora batyr", "Edige", "[[Koroghlu|Koroglu]]" and others.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gertsen |first1=A |title=Crimean Tatars |url=https://bigenc.ru/ethnology/text/5685404 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210308012134/https://bigenc.ru/ethnology/text/5685404 |archive-date=8 March 2021 |access-date=12 July 2021 |website=Big Russian Encyclopedia |publisher=Ministry of Culture of the Russian Federation |language=Russian}}</ref>
+
+Today in use there are two types of alphabet: Cyrillic and Latin. Initially Crimean Tatars used Arabic script. In 1928 it was replaced with the Latin alphabet. Cyrillic was introduced in 1938 based on the Russian alphabet. The Cyrillic alphabet was the only official one between 1938 and 1997. All its letters coincide with those of the Russian alphabet. The 1990s saw the start of the gradual transition of the language to the new Latin alphabet based on the Turkish one.<ref>{{Cite web |date=21 March 2017 |title=Crimean Tatars: A to Z |url=https://uacrisis.org/en/53926-les-tatars-de-crimee-de-z |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220223100710/https://uacrisis.org/en/53926-les-tatars-de-crimee-de-z |archive-date=23 February 2022 |access-date=23 February 2022}}</ref>
 
 === Music ===
 Modern Crimean Tatar and [[Armenians|Armenian]] origins signer, [[Jamala]], won the [[Eurovision Song Contest|Eurovision]] contest in 2016. She sings [[jazz]], soul, funk, folk, pop and electro, and is also the author of most of her songs<ref>{{Cite web |title=Modern culture of the Crimean Tatars |url=https://ukraine.ua/stories/modern-culture-of-the-crimean-tatars/ |website=Official website of Ukraine}}</ref>.

 Traditional peasant folk art, embroidery and vernacular architecture are critical to Ukrainian culture, and its elements have often been determined by the resources available at the time.  Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. +== Canada ==
+{{Main articles|Ukrainian Canadians}}
+First Ukrainians have arrived in Canada in 1891, bringing their Ukrainian traditions with them, which they preserved and propagated, enriching their new home with it, and maintaining their separate ethnicity.<ref>{{Cite thesis |title=Ukrainian cultural traditions in Canada: Theatre, choral music and dance, 1891-1967. |url=http://hdl.handle.net/10393/10564 |publisher=University of Ottawa (Canada) |date=1977 |language=en |first=Alexandra |last=Pritz}}</ref>
+
+Having been separated from Ukraine, Ukrainian Canadians have developed their own distinctive Ukrainian culture in Canada. To showcase their unique hybrid culture, Ukrainian Canadians have created institutions that showcase Ukrainian Canadian culture such as [[Edmonton]]'s [[Cheremosh Ukrainian Dance Company|Cheremosh]] and [[Ukrainian Shumka Dancers|Shumka]] troupes â€“ among the world's elite [[Ukrainian dance|Ukrainian dancers]]; or the [[Ukrainian Cultural Heritage Village]] â€“ a living-history museum approximately 39 kilometres east of Edmonton where Ukrainian [[Post-Confederation Canada (1867â€“1914)#Immigration to the West|pioneer buildings]] are displayed along with extensive cultural exhibits.
+
+Ukrainian Canadians have also contributed to [[Culture of Canada|Canadian culture]] as a whole. Actress and comedian [[Luba Goy]], singer [[Gloria Kaye]],<ref>Czuboka, p. 211-212.</ref> ''[[Jeopardy!]]'' host [[Alex Trebek]], hockey executive [[Kyle Dubas]], and painter [[William Kurelek]], for example, are well known outside the Ukrainian community.
+
+Perhaps one of the most lasting contributions Ukrainian Canadians have made to the wider culture of Canada is the concept of [[multiculturalism]],<ref name="SwyripaLambertEncyc">{{Cite web |last1=Swyripa |first1=Frances A |last2=Lambert |first2=Maude-Emmanuelle |date=December 10, 2021 |title=Ukrainian Canadians |url=https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/ukrainian-canadians |access-date=2 April 2022 |website=[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]] |publisher=[[Historica Canada]]}}</ref><ref name="Cuenco2021">{{Cite journal |last=Cuenco |first=Michael |date=Spring 2021 |title=A Tale of Two Immigration Systems: Canada and the United States |url=https://americanaffairsjournal.org/2021/02/a-tale-of-two-immigration-systems-canada-and-the-united-states/ |journal=[[American Affairs]] |publisher=American Affairs Foundation Inc |volume=V |issue=1}}</ref> which was promoted as early as 1963 by [[Senate of Canada|Senator]] [[Paul Yuzyk]].<ref name="Cuenco2021" /> During and after the debates surrounding the [[Royal Commission on Bilingualism and Biculturalism]], Ukrainian leaders, such as linguist [[Jaroslav Rudnyckyj]], came out in force against the idea of [[Constitutional debate in Canada|English â€“ French]] [[biculturalism]],<ref name="Cuenco2021" /> which they believed denied the contributions other peoples had made to Canada. Partly in response to this, Prime Minister [[Pierre Trudeau]] shifted Canada to a policy of official multiculturalism; notably, the day after the [[Canadian Multiculturalism Policy of 1971]] was officially announced, Trudeau gave a forceful speech in support of the policy at a national assembly of the [[Ukrainian Canadian Congress]] in Winnipeg.<ref name="Cuenco2021" />
+
+== U.S. ==
+{{Main articles|Ukrainian Americans}}
+{{Expand section|date=June 2024}}
+According to U.S. census estimates, in 2021 there were 1,017,586 Americans of Ukrainian descent representing 0.3% of the American population.  The Ukrainian population of the United States is thus the second largest outside the former [[Eastern Bloc]]; only [[Canada]] has a larger [[Ukrainian Canadians|Ukrainian community]] under this definition.
+
+== Brazil ==
+{{Main articles|Ukrainian Brazilians}}
+[[File:Casa_tÃ­pica_de_imigrantes_da_UcrÃ¢nia_no_Brasil_Medium_Size.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian village architecture in [[Curitiba]].]]
+[[File:Memorial_Ucraniano_-_Curitiba.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian church in TingÃ¼i Park, [[Curitiba]].]]
+[[File:Solenidades._Homenagens_(27678560363).jpg|right|thumb|Solemnity for Ukrainians in the [[Senate of Brazil]], in [[BrasÃ­lia]].]]
+[[File:Entrada_da_Igreja_do_Arcanjo_Miguel.jpg|right|thumb|Entrance to the Ukrainian Church in [[Mallet, ParanÃ¡|Mallet]].]]
+Although most Brazilian Ukrainians have lived in Brazil for 4-5 generations and few have ever seen Ukraine,<ref name="rivne">[http://www.rivnepost.rv.ua/showarticle.php?art=018403 ''Rivne Vechirne''] (Evening Rivne). 2003. Issue No. 41 (Ukrainian). Article written by Dmytro Yatsuk.</ref> they have preserved their [[Ukrainian language|language]] and culture to a large degree in rural ParanÃ¡ state.<ref name="Boruszenko">Oksana Boruszenko and Rev. Danyil Kozlinsky (1994). ''Ukrainians in Brazil'' (Chapter), in ''Ukraine and Ukrainians Throughout the World'', edited by Ann Lencyk Pawliczko, University of Toronto Press: Toronto, pp. 443-454</ref> This has largely been due to the colossal efforts of the Ukrainian Churches.<ref name="rivne" /> In contrast, among the [[Ukrainian Argentine|Ukrainians in Argentina]] where the Church was not as strong as in Brazil, the Ukrainian language has largely disappeared.<ref name="den">{{cite news |last=Gudzyk |first=Klara |date=August 23, 2002 |script-title=uk:ÐŸ'ÑÑ‚Ðµ Ð¿Ð¾ÐºÐ¾Ð»Ñ–Ð½Ð½Ñ: Ð£ÐºÑ€Ð°Ñ—Ð½Ñ†Ñ– Ð‘Ñ€Ð°Ð·Ð¸Ð»Ñ–Ñ— Ð·Ð±ÐµÑ€Ñ–Ð³Ð°ÑŽÑ‚ÑŒ ÑÐ²Ð¾Ñ— Ñ‚Ñ€Ð°Ð´Ð¸Ñ†Ñ–Ñ— |trans-title=Fifth generation: Ukrainians of Brazil preserve their traditions |url=https://day.kyiv.ua/uk/article/cuspilstvo/pyate-pokolinnya |access-date=January 7, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Day (Kiev)|The Day]] |language=uk}}</ref>
+
+Among those who live in the colonies, or agricultural settlements, Ukrainian is widely spoken at home, in church, and in the community, and today it is not uncommon for Ukrainian children to be unable to speak the Portuguese language until they begin school. Despite the Ukrainian language's widespread use in everyday speech, the ability to read and write is more limited, with over 50% of the Ukrainian population being unable to write in the Ukrainian language.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20191218192140/http://rius.kiev.ua/Diaspora/boru ''Brazilian Ukraine and Globalization.''] Borushenko, O.P. Professor, Federal University of ParanÃ¡. Text of his presentation "Diaspora as a Leader in Support for the Ukrainian State in International Relations. June 18â€“20, 2008.</ref>
+
+Due to isolation from Ukraine, the Ukrainians of Brazil speak a 100-year-old form of the language's [[Ukrainian dialects|Galician or "Upper Dniestrian" dialect]].<ref name="rivne" /> Ninety percent of Church services are conducted in the Ukrainian language (in contrast, among the 700,000 [[Polish Brazilian|ethnic Poles in Brazil]] only two churches use the Polish language).<ref name="den" />
+
+The Portuguese language has only come into wide use in the youngest generation - those who are younger than fifteen years old.<ref name="rivne" /> ParanÃ¡ boasts five [[Ukrainian-language]] radio stations,<ref name="den" /> including "Zabava" which broadcasts news, Ukrainian folk and pop music, and the [[Divine Liturgy]].<ref name="rivne" /> In addition, Brazil has 23 Ukrainian dance troupes.<ref name="CIUS">Press Release. [https://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/announce/media/Media%202009/2009-06-29_Ukrainian%20Life%20in%20Brazil%20(eng).pdf Scholars Impressed with Ukrainian Life in Brazil.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515191940/http://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/announce/media/Media%202009/2009-06-29_Ukrainian%20Life%20in%20Brazil%20(eng).pdf|date=May 15, 2013}} Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies, University of Alberta. 2009</ref> In the rural areas, Ukrainians rarely marry non-Ukrainians, and mixed marriages generally adopt the Ukrainian culture.<ref name="Boruszenko" />
+
+The Ukrainians' neighbors - [[Caboclo|Caboclos]], Poles, Germans, Italians, and some Dutch - at times accuse the Ukrainians and their priests of maintaining an exclusiveness that sometimes borders on racism, although non-Brazilians who visit the local Ukrainians are treated with the utmost civility.<ref name="pitravel">[http://www.pacificislandtravel.com/south_america/brazil/about_destin/southcentralparana.html Pacific Island Travel web-site, accessed 4.8.08] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080903043907/http://www.pacificislandtravel.com/south_america/brazil/about_destin/southcentralparana.html|date=September 3, 2008}}, taken from: ''Brazil: the Rough Guide'', by David Cleary, Dilwyn Jenkins, Oliver Marshall, Jim Hine. {{ISBN|1-85828-223-3}}</ref> Ukrainians in Brazil commonly refer to themselves and to Ukrainians from other countries as "our people" (''Nashi Liudy'') and to non-Ukrainians of any nationality as "blacks" (''Chorni'').<ref name="rivne" />
+
+The situation in urban areas is quite different. In the cities, Ukrainians tend to become assimilated into Brazilian culture<ref name="Boruszenko" /> and to adopt the [[Portuguese language]].<ref name="rivne" />
+
 === Music ===
 Modern Crimean Tatar and [[Armenians|Armenian]] origins signer, [[Jamala]], won the [[Eurovision Song Contest|Eurovision]] contest in 2016. She sings [[jazz]], soul, funk, folk, pop and electro, and is also the author of most of her songs<ref>{{Cite web |title=Modern culture of the Crimean Tatars |url=https://ukraine.ua/stories/modern-culture-of-the-crimean-tatars/ |website=Official website of Ukraine}}</ref>.
